Introduction

Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) refers to a group of rare but malignant disorders arising from placental trophoblasts.  It includes invasive mole, choriocarcinoma, placental site trophoblastic tumor (PSTT), and epithelioid trophoblastic tumor (ETT).  These disorders occur following pregnancy and may lead to persistent abnormal vaginal bleeding and positive β-hCG.



"Gestational trophoblastic disease" (GTD) is a broader term that includes the GTNs and benign disorders (eg, complete hydatidiform mole, partial hydatidiform mole) that arise from abnormal proliferation of placental trophoblasts.

Pathogenesis



Early in pregnancy, the blastocyst develops a layer of trophoblastic cells that implant into the endometrium and form the placenta (

figure 1
).  Abnormal fertilization events or mutations can lead to neoplasia (ie, persistent abnormal cellular proliferation) of these trophoblastic cells, leading to GTN.  GTN is therefore genetically distinct from the patient because it arises from placental (fetal) tissue.  Unlike in a normal pregnancy, the trophoblastic cells of GTN have the potential to invade the myometrium and metastasize.



GTN can develop following any type of pregnancy:  Approximately 50% of cases occur after a molar pregnancy, 25% after a term or preterm pregnancy, and 25% after an ectopic pregnancy or spontaneous abortion.



GTN is divided into the following subtypes:



  • Invasive mole:  Arises from the invasion of abnormal villi of molar tissue into the myometrium or vascular spaces.  It typically arises from a complete hydatidiform mole but rarely from a partial mole.
  • Choriocarcinoma:  Arises from the villous trophoblast following any gestational event and spreads hematogenously as an aggressive malignancy.  It is also referred to as gestational choriocarcinoma to distinguish it from nongestational (ovarian) choriocarcinoma, a rare type of ovarian germ cell tumor.
  • PSTT and ETT:  Account for only 1% of GTN cases (extremely rare).  They arise from intermediate trophoblast cells.  They most often occur following a term pregnancy but may not present until years later because they are typically slow growing.

Risk factors



  • Previous hydatidiform mole (especially complete hydatidiform mole):  The risk is further increased if the molar pregnancy had associated theca lutein cysts (ie, bilaterally enlarged, multicystic ovaries), a hCG level >100,000 IU/L, or significant uterine enlargement.
  • Age >40.
  • Prior GTN.

Pathology



  • Invasive mole:  Invasion of hydropic molar villi into the myometrium with extensive trophoblastic proliferation.  It can also invade the uterine vasculature, and approximately 15% become metastatic, often to the vagina or lungs.
  • Choriocarcinoma:  Sheets of cytotrophoblasts and syncytiotrophoblasts (which produce high levels of β-hCG) without villous structures.  Choriocarcinomas tend to be highly hemorrhagic and necrotic and demonstrate vascular invasion.
  • PSTT:  Sheets or cords of monomorphic intermediate trophoblastic cells infiltrating the myometrium, usually with minimal vascular invasion and necrosis.
  • ETT:  Primarily, nests of monomorphic intermediate trophoblasts, usually with less vascular invasion and a nodular growth pattern.  ETT resembles carcinoma.  Areas of necrosis and scattered syncytiotrophoblasts (leading to low-level β-hCG production) may be present.  ETT tends to involve the lower uterine segment and cervix.

Clinical presentation



GTN most often presents with persistent or irregular vaginal bleeding weeks to months following a pregnancy, but some patients have amenorrhea.  β-hCG is positive and, if significantly elevated, may cause hyperemesis gravidarum, theca lutein cysts, or hyperthyroidism.



Less commonly, local invasion of tumor cells through the myometrium can cause uterine rupture, leading to vaginal and intraabdominal bleeding, abdominal pain, and hemodynamic instability.  GTN can also present with symptoms of metastases:



  • Lungs:  Cough, hemoptysis, chest pain, dyspnea.
  • Vagina:  Vaginal bleeding.
  • Brain:  Headaches, seizures, neurologic deficits.
  • Liver:  Jaundice, right upper quadrant pain.

Invasive mole



Invasive mole classically presents with a rising or plateauing β-hCG weeks to months after surgical evacuation of a molar pregnancy.

Choriocarcinoma



Choriocarcinoma usually occurs following a molar pregnancy.  However, it is the most common type of GTN to occur after a nonmolar pregnancy.  It is aggressive, produces abundant β-hCG (possibly >100,000 IU/L), metastasizes early, and frequently presents with bleeding from a metastatic site.

PSTT and ETT



PSTT and ETT typically occur months to years after a pregnancy, which is most often a term pregnancy.  They are frequently diagnosed late because they tend to be slow growing, produce low levels of β-hCG (<1,000 IU/L), and cause few symptoms.  Up to 50% have metastases at diagnosis.

Differential diagnosis



  • Retained products of conception:  Some placental or fetal tissue may remain in the uterus following abortion or delivery, leading to heavy bleeding and a dilated cervix.  A subacute presentation (persistent abnormal uterine bleeding or amenorrhea over the following weeks to months) is also possible.  Ultrasonography demonstrates a heterogeneous echogenic mass in the endometrial cavity, and β-hCG may be positive.  There is significant overlap between the presentation of GTN and the retained products of conception; if the preceding pregnancy was molar, GTN is the presumed diagnosis.
  • Ectopic pregnancy:  Ectopic pregnancies cause abnormal uterine bleeding; nonvisualization of an intrauterine pregnancy also occurs despite a positive β-hCG.  However, ultrasonography often demonstrates a thin endometrial stripe and an adnexal mass.  In contrast, imaging in patients with GTN reveals a uterine mass and possibly metastatic lesions.
  • Normal early pregnancy:  An early pregnancy may not be visible on ultrasonography, but β-hCG levels rise predictably over time, and an intrauterine pregnancy becomes visible in the subsequent weeks.
  • Uterine cancer (eg, carcinoma, sarcoma):  Cancer may present with abnormal uterine bleeding and findings of a uterine mass on ultrasonography.  Unlike GTN, uterine cancers are more likely to occur in postmenopausal women, and β-hCG is negative.
  • hCG-producing neoplasms:  Some ovarian germ cell tumors and nongynecologic cancers (eg, liver, pancreas, stomach) can produce hCG.  Imaging studies can be used to identify the site of the primary cancer.

Diagnosis



Unlike most other solid tumors, in GTN, a histologic evaluation is not required for diagnosis.  The tumor and metastatic sites are highly vascular and generally should not be biopsied because this can lead to hemorrhage.  Instead, GTN is diagnosed clinically in patients with persistent β-hCG elevation following a pregnancy after other causes of high β-hCG have been excluded.  Occasionally, a histologic diagnosis is provided after surgical management.

Laboratory evaluation



β-hCG testing is critical for diagnosis:



  • Following a molar pregnancy:  After treatment of a molar pregnancy (with either dilation and evacuation or hysterectomy), serial β-hCG levels are followed regularly until they are persistently negative.  GTN is diagnosed if there is a rise or plateau in β-hCG levels over several weeks.
  • Following a nonmolar pregnancy:  GTN is diagnosed if β-hCG is elevated and all other potential causes (eg, new pregnancy, spontaneous abortion, ectopic pregnancy, heterophile antibodies, other hCG-secreting tumor, pituitary hCG) are ruled out.

Imaging studies



  • Pelvic ultrasonography:  All patients with suspected GTN.  A uterine mass with hypervascularity is typically demonstrated on Doppler ultrasonography and invasion into the myometrium.  Ultrasonography also rules out an ectopic or intrauterine pregnancy and evaluates the degree of tumor spread within the pelvis.
  • Chest x-ray:  All patients with suspected GTN because the lungs are the most common site for metastasis.
  • Additional imaging:  Patients with suspicion for metastatic disease (eg, vaginal lesions on examination, neurologic symptoms, evidence of metastasis on chest x-ray).  These patients should have further imaging to evaluate the extent of disease spread.  This usually includes brain imaging (MRI or CT scan) and CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis.

Staging



GTN is typically surgically staged:



  • Stage I:  No spread beyond the uterus.
  • Stage II:  Tumor spread to the adnexa or vagina.
  • Stage III:  Metastasis to the lungs.
  • Stage IV:  Metastasis beyond the pelvis, vagina, and lungs.


Invasive mole and choriocarcinoma are also assigned a risk score, which is used to identify patients at increased risk for resistance to single-agent chemotherapy.  The scoring system considers patient age, type of antecedent pregnancy, tumor size, β-hCG level, and size and number of metastases.

Management

Invasive mole and choriocarcinoma



Invasive mole and choriocarcinoma are highly chemosensitive; therefore, chemotherapy is the primary mode of treatment.  Cancer stage and risk score are considered to categorize patients as low or high risk to determine the chemotherapy regimen, with low-risk patients usually treated with a single chemotherapy agent and high-risk patients requiring multiagent chemotherapy and possible adjuvant surgery.



Patients should be monitored with laboratory studies while receiving chemotherapy to evaluate response to treatment (declining β-hCG levels) and potential toxicities (cytopenias, hepatic injury).  Remission is achieved when weekly β-hCG is undetectable for 3 consecutive weeks.  After completion of treatment, β-hCG should be followed monthly for 12-24 months to detect recurrence.

PSTT and ETT



Because of their slow-growing natures, most PSTT and ETT cancers are relatively resistant to chemotherapy, and treatment is typically surgical with hysterectomy and salpingectomy.  Patients with metastatic disease typically also require chemotherapy and additional surgical resection of metastatic lesions (if possible).



β-hCG should be followed monthly after treatment is completed.  However, because it is a less reliable tumor marker for these types of GTN, patients are also followed with positron emission tomography–CT scan every 6-12 months for several years.

Prognosis



Low-risk invasive mole and choriocarcinoma have excellent prognoses; there is a 100% cure rate overall, and up to 85% of patients achieve complete remission using only single-agent chemotherapy.  Survival also exceeds 70% for metastatic disease, although the presence of brain or liver metastases is associated with lower survival.



PSTT and ETT have a 100% cure rate if cancer is confined to the uterus; survival decreases to 50%-60% for patients with metastatic disease.

Prevention



Most cases of GTN occur following molar pregnancies.  Early detection strategies improve outcomes for GTN and include postmolar surveillance (

figure 2
).  After surgical treatment of a molar pregnancy, β-hCG levels are followed weekly until they are persistently negative and are then followed monthly.  During this time, patients require contraception for accurate interpretation of serial β-hCG measurements because a newly conceived pregnancy creates diagnostic confusion.

Summary



Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia is a rare but highly treatable condition if detected early.  It should always be considered in women with persistent vaginal bleeding and elevated β-hCG after any pregnancy event.  Subtypes include an invasive mole, choriocarcinoma, placental site trophoblastic tumor, and epithelioid trophoblastic tumor.
